title: Night of the Unmooring
description: Lanterns bloom across the Tess and the Vail like constellations finding their reflections, each wick-boat a whispered vow, each flame a debt set adrift to gentle waters. The terraces of Vyratha glow copper-green and saffron-gold, and even the knives of the Night Ledger usually sleep under the festival’s truce, but rumor stirs like a sly current beneath the songs. Whispers say the Indigosatchel Consortium will loose a crafted panic so they can be seen to quell it, arguing the city needs private guardianship, while the Night Ledger means to enact a grand erasure in the commotion, washing a bloody feud clean by drowning a name in fear. Sava Deren, stern as an oarlock and steady as a keel, calls Aren Siltwarden to walk the bright edge between grace and order, to keep the lanterns unspilled and the city from trampling itself into the river. Brass Menders ready their bell-tree codes to soothe without compulsion, and a dwarven resonance ring from Seven-Kettle hums at the edge of hearing, a tool that might blend the crowd’s hymn to the river’s oldest note if guided by a careful hand. The night shivers with promise and peril, and the city must sing before it bleeds.
objectives: Coordinate discreetly with Brass Menders bell-ringers to broadcast calming codes across the banks.
Use the resonance ring to harmonize the crowd’s chant with the river’s unknown note without causing a surge.
Identify and thwart a staged panic by Indigosatchel agents and prevent a Night Ledger erasure from claiming an innocent.
Keep the wick-boats safe from sabotage while preserving the sanctity of the festival.

dialogue.speaker: Sava Deren
dialogue.lines: This night belongs to the river and to those who remember their dead by light, not to ledger-men staging heroics for tomorrow’s broadsheets. I have broken strikes and I have broken bread, but I will not break the Lantern Unmooring for anyone’s account book, not even my own guild’s. My ferries will hold the channels and my crews will hold their tempers if they see that you are holding the center, because they trust you not to sell a calm for a coin. Keep the bells soft and the people softer, and I will keep the boats from kissing hull to hull until they scrape sparks. If a panic starts, it will not be our hands that molded it, and if blood is spilled, it will not be ours that washed it down the steps. Do the soft work with iron steadiness, Aren, and I will meet you in the middle with nothing broken but a few bad plans.

dialogue.speaker: Calra Orun
dialogue.lines: Spectacle is an investment that pays back in trust, and sometimes the city needs to see whose hands can catch it when it staggers. If the crowd feels safe, they will not spit on contracts they cannot begin to understand, because security is the first clause of every social oath whether written or felt. I do not intend harm, Aren; I intend proof, and proof often wears the same mask as danger until the reveal. Remove the agitators and you remove my necessity, but if necessity remains, I would prefer the story to end with my seal on the rescue and the Conclave nodding that private guardianship is prudence, not greed. Consider the math of reputation as carefully as you read a current, because a controlled wave can clean a channel as surely as a flood can drown it. Walk with me rather than against me, and perhaps we both leave with clean hands and full coffers and a city that sleeps easier for having watched competence perform.

dialogue.speaker: Jilai Sunquiet
dialogue.lines: The bell-tree sings in patterns that people’s bodies understand before their minds do, like a mother’s hum remembered from a fevered night. A low triplet calms the breath, a rising fifth unknots the shoulders, and a long, patient cadence tells the frightened that time still belongs to them. We will ring only what soothes and never what compels, because the Menders mend by consent and comfort, not by domination hidden in melody. I will post ringers on each bank and two on the bridges, and we will listen to you when you signal, because we know you carry a calm even when others carry steel. If you must cut a rumor free from the crowd, cut it softly with a bell rather than a blade, and we will wrap the wound in song until it forgets it was ever hurt. Bring me your plan in phrases and pauses, and I will hang them like chimes where the wind of fear cannot catch them.

dialogue.speaker: Thorek Brimvauld
dialogue.lines: The resonance ring is a dwarf’s modest answer to a human panic, forged in Seven-Kettle where the kettles teach you whether your note is truer than your fear. Hold it at your breastbone and speak a tone that means home to you, and it will bloom a chord that threads through nearby throats and asks them to hum, not shout. Do not chase the unknown note at the Weir, because that gate answers a singer who has not yet been born, and a festival is no cradle for such experiments. Bleed the ring too long and it will drink your strength like a thirsty apprentice, so use it in sips and let the bells do their part. If you must cut through noise, cut a small window of silence where a word like ‘easy’ can crawl in and build a nest. I will walk with you and listen to the metal, because metal knows when footsteps will turn to a stampede before feet admit it.

dialogue.speaker: Yerin Pale
dialogue.lines: Debts sleep lightly on nights like this, and some of them wake hungry for spectacle, but I would rather feed them ink than blood if balance can be achieved. The Ledger’s erasures are not murders in our minds, though the city says otherwise; we call them reconciliations, and you may spit at the word as many honest people do. There is a name that ought to pass, and there is a crowd that will give us cover, but cover is not the same as consent, and I do not mistake those two unless necessity argues cruelly. Offer me a better arithmetic, Aren, and I can make a page go white without dropping a body, but I will ask you to sign a margin with something costly in its own way. Do not threaten me with bells or boats; threaten me with a future in which tonight’s chaos makes trade limp for a season, and I will listen because I live by moving numbers, not by stopping hearts. I will not promise kindness, but I can promise discretion, and sometimes that is the softer of the two knives.

dialogue.speaker: Mereth Tydel
dialogue.lines: The Nine Tides remember when we sing them true, and the Lantern Unmooring is the city’s way of telling grief to float without sinking the living. I will give you a blessing of Lull, which is patience that does not yawn, and of Slackwater, which is strength that does not show off. Keep your hands open where fear expects fists, and speak to the river as if it were an old friend who has seen you foolish and still invites you to sit. If you must name the panic by name, do it once and then never again, because names grow larger when you feed them attention, and we want this one to starve. Remember that the river will take any excuse to teach us humility, so do not give it the excuse of arrogance or the rope of carelessness. Walk slow where others run, and let people match your pace because calm is contagious when it has a body to wear.

dialogue.speaker: Aren Siltwarden
dialogue.lines: Trust is not a coin you mint, it is a ferry you pole across water that laughs at plans, and I have poled through worse weather than a handful of hired shouts. Keep your agents leashed, Calra, or we will all be fishing for names and children in the dark, and the river keeps what it is given when the giving is stupid. Sava, I will ring the bells soft and hold the channels wide with my voice instead of my blade, because a night like this deserves chorus not clamor. Jilai, listen for my pauses more than my words, because the crowd will feel the rests as surely as the notes and follow the space we make. Thorek, I will use the ring as a whisper, not a horn, and if the unknown note answers, it will be because the river chooses to hum back, not because I dragged it into the air. And if the Night Ledger reaches for a throat in the smoke, I will put my hand between reach and breath and call it a toll the river will not take tonight.

choices.title: Weave Bells and Bridges
choices.text: You choose to stand with the Brass Menders and the Ferrymen in quiet concert, mapping the festival like a river chart and placing bell-ringers where the current of fear would most like to run. You keep the resonance ring close and use it only to stitch small rents in the hymn, never to drown or dazzle, letting human voices carry human calm. When the first planted shout rises, you answer not with a counter-shout but with a rhythm that makes people breathe together, and the rumor that was meant to sprint finds its shoelace tied by music. You walk the embankments at a steady pace that others match without thinking, and your hands show open and empty except for lanterns you lift and pass along. You listen for the Ledger’s footfall and for the Consortium’s script, and you make your way to the center before either can seize it, trading spectacle for steadiness in a market of attention. The night becomes a gently braided rope of light and breath, and you hold it together with knots tied in time.
choices.outcome: The staged panic frays without ever pulling taut, because every time someone yanks, the bell-tree hums slack into the line and the crowd refuses to tighten. Indigosatchel’s agents find themselves applauding a calm they did not purchase, and their narrative of necessary guardianship goes home with its boots still muddy and its rhetoric unimpressive. A Ledger knife hesitates at your shoulder and then moves on because there is no cover for an erasure when people are looking at one another instead of at their own fear, and the intended innocent leaves the night with a lantern instead of a name-shaped hole. Sava’s crews never have to lock poles, and the wick-boats drift their script unbroken, so the river reads grief and gratitude rather than panic and profit. In the aftermath whispers call you dull and dangerous in the same breath, which is the city’s highest praise for a guardian who did not make a show of guarding. You end the night with quiet thanks, a heavier pocket, and a sense that the river’s unknown note approved without needing to be heard.

choices.title: Broker the Calculated Wave
choices.text: You step under Calra Orun’s shade for a brief and risky bargain, agreeing to funnel the first tremor into a shallow basin where her hired response can look grand and cost little. You mark out a corridor for the crowd that feels like choice even as it is guided, and you keep the resonance ring humming enough to prevent the wave from slapping the stone too hard. You warn her that if the Ledger moves during the display, the show ends, and she gives you a tight little nod that says she understands leverage even when she does not like its wielder. You coordinate a single bell peal that sounds like a surprise and then a second that sounds like relief, cuing her folk to appear at just the right time to collect applause like tithe. You walk beside the spectacle like a parent walking beside a running child, ready to catch, ready to scold, and ready to end the game if a knee goes wrong. You keep your face flat and your stance open, selling calm even as the market around you buys theater.
choices.outcome: The crowd swells and then settles with a cheer that makes Calra’s auditors smile into their sleeves, and the next morning’s broadsheets sketch a neat little story about prudent private guardianship. The Ledger tries to slip an erasure beneath the clap but finds your hand on the shoulder they were hunting, and the would-be victim ends the night drinking hot tea instead of water. Sava’s mouth is a hard line because she despises borrowed panic even when it returns unharmed, and some Ferrymen mutter that you let a merchant turn the river into a stage. The Menders’ bell-keepers forgive you with thin smiles because harm was avoided, but they note that you turned medicine into applause and promise to watch your prescriptions more closely. Indigosatchel’s esteem rises a notch while your conscience lowers by the same margin, and you taste the silt of compromise as you walk home. The wick-boats write their script with a small wobble in the middle, like a stutter in a beautiful sentence that most readers miss but you cannot unread.

choices.title: Cut a Ledger Line in White
choices.text: You seek Yerin Pale in the hush between bridges and make an offer pitched in arithmetic rather than outrage, wagering that a bloodless equation can balance a night that forbids knives. You promise to burn a debt-thread in the Hollowwind Barrows that the Ledger has stored for a day like this, a page turning white without a throat turning blue, if he calls off the erasure now. You explain how a public panic will sour trade for a season and break three small treaties by memory alone, and you show him the clean lines of a ledger that runs smooth because this night ran smooth. You let him see your dislike without making it an insult, because respect in Vyratha is sometimes only the absence of disdain shown well. You tell him that if he insists on a spectacle, you will make it a spectacle of his choice to drown a name in a night of lanterns, and he measures the cost then to a decimal you never see. You stand on a line between righteousness and utility and you invite him to stand there with you for one night only.
choices.outcome: Yerin withdraws his hand from the night like a scribe lifting a quill from wet ink, and the name that would have vanished stays writ in the city a little longer, alive and wary. You later keep your side of the bargain with a funeral for paper rather than a funeral for flesh, burning a debt-thread in the Barrows while the Hollow Choir sighs approval that no breath left a body. The Ledger’s respect for you hardens into that peculiar alloy of irritation and admiration that keeps knives sheathed and eyes always watching. Sava nods at you in the way of tough captains who approve of quiet deals that keep water from reddening, and the Menders pour you a cup that tastes like trust more than tea. Calra’s people grumble because you denied them a chaos tidy enough to monetize, and a rumor appears that you prefer back rooms to brave rooms, which you neither deny nor invite. The wick-boats float untroubled, and the river swallows the taste of what nearly was and finds it acceptable.

choices.title: Sing the Unknown, Risk the Surge
choices.text: You raise the resonance ring to your sternum and close your eyes until the festival becomes breath and pulse, then you risk a tone you have only ever heard in dreams of a dry riverbed where memories swim like minnows. You do not force it with volume but with honesty, letting your throat admit fear and love and grief until the ring warms like a held hand, and you trust the crowd to hear your trust. The note that answers is not the Weir’s forbidden pitch but something kin to it, a cousin born of lanterns and low water, and it passes along the terraces like a cloud deciding to be shade instead of storm. In the wake of the sound, you walk, and the bells walk with you, and even the paid shouters forget their script for half a minute because the body they live in chooses to listen. You know if you push again you will crack the night like thin ice, so you let the single sweep of music stand alone as a roof under which everyone briefly shares a room. You plant your pole at the water’s edge, not to steer but to show where the ground ends and the river begins, which is what people needed to remember.
choices.outcome: The crowd settles with a shiver that releases rather than clenches, and for a smiling minute Vyratha breathes like one creature with many ribs, a rare animal that startles and then laughs at itself with relief. A small surge curls its lip at the stone and then lies back down, tempted but not invited to become a tantrum, and you feel the fatigue bite into your bones like cold iron. The Ledger’s knife cannot find the rhythm to slip through and retreats with a promise scratched on air that you will read later whether you want to or not. Calra’s agents miss their cues and report failure with the kind of professionalism that demands a scapegoat, and your name appears on a few lists underlined in a tidy hand. Sava throws you a look that holds the river’s thanks, and Jilai’s bell-keepers write your breath into their sequence chart as an impossible note described by metaphor rather than frequency. The wick-boats drift their slow scripture unbroken, and when the last flame goes out, the river keeps your secret and your strength until morning, when it gives you back enough to stand.

rewards.description: 22 Vyrathan silver scales as a hazard stipend from the Ferrymen, counted clean and sealed against damp.
Ferrymen Tide-Marker, a river-token granting priority docking in emergencies when shown at any guild wharf.
Bell-Tree Sequence Chart, a compact roll of calming and alert codes used by the Brass Menders for citywide signaling.
Guild of Silver Ferrymen reputation +2 for keeping channels clear and lanterns unspilled during the Unmooring.
Indigosatchel Consortium reputation -1 for frustrating their planned demonstration of private guardianship.
Night Ledger reputation -1 for denying an erasure and complicating shadow arithmetic.
Brass Menders reputation +1 for using bell-tree codes with restraint and care.
Temporary command over festival watch crews during crises, recognized by sash and bell-signal for the season’s remaining rites.
